parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>RV</title><part><name>type</name>=<value>command

</value></part><part><name>game1</name>=<value> arma3

</value></part><part><name>version1</name>=<value> 1.16

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> DLC

</value></part><part><name>descr</name>=<value> Returns array of app IDs of DLCs.

</value></part><part><name>s1</name>=<value> [[getDLCs]] filter

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value>  filter: [[Number]] - can be:
* 0 - all
* 1 - owned
* 2 - not owned

</value></part><part><name>r1</name>=<value> [[Array]] - Array of DLC numbers.

</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>_ownedDLCs = [[getDLCs]] 1;</code>

</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> <code>_hasKarts = (288520 [[in]] ([[getDLCs]] 1));</code>

</value></part><part><name>seealso</name>=<value> [[getObjectDLC]], [[getPersonUsedDLCs]], [[getMissionDLCs]], [[getDLCAssetsUsageByName]], [[getDLCAssetsUsage]], [[getAssetDLCInfo]]
</value></part></template>

<dl class="command_description">
<dd class="notedate">Posted on April 7, 2015 - 20:27 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Benargee|Benargee]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
App ID can be found in CfgMods. Here is an example path from zeus using the Splendid Config Viewer:
<code>[[configFile]] >> "CfgMods" >> "Curator" >> "appId"</code>
This method can be used to find app IDs without having to find a list like the one above.<br>
I am also pretty sure you are able to define your own app ID for your own mods using this method.
</dd>
</dl></root>
